node.title: Reserve Bank bond-buying to end in May unless economy falters, Lowe says
node.alt: Lowe is at a podium, wearing a dark suit and tie, looking to the right of the camera.
node.description: The Reserve Bank governor lays out the options for its stimulus programs next year, with the outcome depending largely on the Omicron outbreak.
node.content:
["The Reserve Bank governor has laid out the options for its stimulus programs next year, with the outcome depending largely on the Omicron outbreak.", "Speaking at a business function in his home town of Wagga Wagga, RBA governor Philip Lowe offered a clear outline of how the bank expected\u00a0to wind down its bond-buying, or \"quantitative easing\", program next year.", "In a statement after last week's RBA board meeting, Dr Lowe outlined the factors the bank would consider at its February meeting in winding down its $4 billion a week of government bond purchases.", "In today's speech, he presented three options the board had discussed in December\u00a0for how it might be done.", "\"The first option discussed was to further taper the bond purchases from the current rate of $4 billion a week, with an expectation that the purchases would come to an end in May,\" he explained.", "\"The second was to taper further and then review the situation again in May.", "\"The third option was to cease bond purchases altogether in February.\"", "", "
The Reserve Bank had said that interest rates were unlikely to rise until 2024, but has recently softened that stance.(ABC News: Michael Janda)
", "Dr Lowe then revealed that option one was the board's base case if the economy continued its recovery as currently expected.", "\"If better-than-expected progress towards the board's goals was made, then the case to cease bond purchases in February would be stronger.", "\"Alternatively, if progress is slower than expected, or if the outlook becomes more uncertain, the case for retaining flexibility and reviewing again in May would be stronger.\"", "
More than $200b in savings to spend
", "Currently, there are two factors pushing the economy towards meeting or exceeding the Reserve Bank's forecasts.", "\"Spending was more resilient than we had expected, providing further evidence that households and businesses are adjusting to living with the virus,\" Dr Lowe observed, referring to the period of the lockdowns across south-eastern Australia.", "Going forward, the RBA governor was also made optimistic by the savings\u00a0that Australians accumulated while many were stuck at home.", "\"Typically, in an economic downturn households dip into their savings,\" Dr Lowe observed.", "\"In the September quarter, the household saving rate surged to near 20 per cent as governments supported incomes at a time when it was hard to spend.", "\"We estimate that the total additional savings by households during the pandemic has amounted to more than $200 billion and many businesses have also increased their cash reserves.", "\"Provided people have the ability to spend \u2013 and the confidence to do so \u2013 these additional savings will support strong growth in consumption over coming months.\"", "However, Dr Lowe had one big caveat \u2014 the Omicron variant and other developments in the COVID-19 pandemic and public health response.", "\"The Omicron outbreak does, though, represent a downside risk and it is difficult to know how things will develop from here,\" he warned.", "So, like most of us, the Reserve Bank boss is waiting to see whether his plans for a summer break are disrupted by this new COVID variant."]
